groups.label: Do you take medication to help sleep?
Do you take any medication to stay awake?
Have you worked a prolonged shift previously
Have you had difficulty with sleep associated with shift work?
Are the people in your life (family and friends) associated with shift work?
Do they support your decision to commence shift work?
How much sleep do you get on average?
How much sleep do you require to feel refreshed the next day?
How long on average does it take for you to fall asleep?
How do you rate your quality of sleep?
Are you aware if you ever stop breathing or does your breath hold whilst sleeping
How would you rate your level of physical activity?
How often do you partake in vigorous exercise per week?
How many hours per week do you spend at work?
How do you rate your diet?
How often do you eat high fat and/or high sugar foods (e.g. fried/fast foods, pies etc.)?
Please indicate the options which best apply regarding the likelihood of falling asleep in various situations over the past 2 weeks.
Sitting, inactive in public (e.g. Bus, theatre)
Sitting as a passenger in a car?
Lying down to rest in the afternoon?
Sitting quietly after eating a meal during the day (no alcohol)
In the car, whilst stopped at traffic for a few minutes?

I authorise the examining medical practitioner to provide the results of my medical examination to the employer. I also consent to the allow my general practitioner/other treating doctor to release details of relevant medical conditions to the Redimed Medical centre. 

I have read the above statements. The answers are correct, and no information concerning my present or past health has been withheld.

SURVEY

Sleep is a key factor influencing a drivers ability to maintain alertness, attention and safe driving performance for prolonged periods, especially when driving heavy vehicles. With increased levels of sleepiness, the tendency to doze and consequent accident risk is also increased.

 

Sleepiness is increased by sleep deprivation and also by some chronic sleep disorders, the commonest of which is obstructive sleep apnoea. With such a disorder the person has increased sleepiness during the day, even after sleeping for many hours during the night.

 

Obstructive sleep apnoea syndrome (OSAS) involves excessive daytime sleepiness, heavy snoring and frequent episodes of obstructed breathing when asleep. It is made worse by hereditary and other factors which determines the size and collapsibility of the oropharyngea and nasal airway, by obesity and by alcohol consumption.

 

For screening purposes some of these variables can be assessed by responses to a questionnaire, such as  the ATA survey, which determines the general level of daytime sleepiness, obesity, alcohol consumption and reports from others in regards to snoring and sleep apnoea.

 

Some characteristics of the upper airway can be assessed by a brief physical examination. However accurate assessment of OSAS requires overnight monitoring in a sleep laboratory.

MEASURING SLEEPINESS

In the assessment of sleep habits and sleep disorders, a person's general level of sleepiness during the day is an important criteria.

 

The Multiple Sleep Latency Test (MSLT) is widely used to measure daytime sleepiness but is time-consuming and expensive. Other alternatives such as the Stanford Sleepiness Scale (SSS) and the Sleep-Wake Activity Inventory (SWAI) also have disadvantages.

 

However, the Epworth Sleepiness Scale (ESS) is a simple method for measuring the general level of daytime sleepiness or sleep propensity in adults.

 

The ESS has been scientifically validated (Refs 1-3) and ESS scores distinguish patients with primary snoring from those with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea syndrome(OSAS).

 

The ESS is a brief, self-administered questionnaire that asks the subject to rate on a scale of 0-3 the chances that over 'recent limes' he would have dozed in eight specific situations that are commonly met in daily life (O = would never doze, whilst 3 = high chance of dozing). The ESS score is simply the sum of the eight item scores and thus can range from 0-24.

 

The clinically normal range of ESS scores is 2 to 10, with a normal distribution statistically and a model score of 6.

 

Patients with insomnia often have very low ESS scores between 0 and 2, whilst patients with OSAS have high scores greater than 10. ESS scores increase with the severity of OSAS. However ESS scores are not diagnostic of OSAS for other sleep disorders can also increase sleepiness.

MEASURING OBESITY

The most readily measured indicator is Body Mass Index which is the weight of the subject in kilograms divided by the height squared. The ATA questionnaire covers both weight and height so that the BMI calculation can be easily done.


         BMl = WEIGHT (kilograms) / HEIGHT (metres)2


        Normal BMI = 20-25


        Overweight =  25.1 -29.9


        Obese         = 30 +

 

Physical signs indicative of OSOS

  • The subject may or may not appear sleepy to you, for any examination procedure can temporarily overcome even high levels of daytime sleepiness.
  • A crowded oropharynx with a long, inflamed uvula and soft palate, sometimes with enlarged tonsils. 
  • A relatively small mandible and/or a large tongue.
  • A blocked nose due to septal deviation, polys or swollen turbinates, etc. 
  • A thick neck with a fat pad under the mandible
  • Signs of hypothyroidism.

INDICATIONS FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION

The following suggest the need for further investigation and perhaps referral to a sleep clinic.

a.) ESS score greater than 15.

b.) ESS score greater than 12 when combined with:

  Snoring most days or every day ;

  Stopped breathing frequently

  Any of the physical signs above

  Obesity that is BMI greater than 30

c.) Poor or very poor quality sleep.

d.) Frequently taking more than 30 minutes to fall asleep at night and frequently taking medication to sleep.

e.) Obtaining very little sleep, that is less than 4 hours per 24 hours.

 

References: Johns M.W. Sleep 1991; \4-540-5/johns M.W. Sleep 1992: 15(4): 376-381 / Johns M.W. Ches11993; 103: 30-36

  Obesity that is BMI greater than 30

c.) Poor or very poor quality sleep.

d.) Frequently taking more than 30 minutes to fall asleep at night and frequently taking medication to sleep.

e.) Obtaining very little sleep, that is less than 4 hours per 24 hours.

 

References: Johns M.W. Sleep 1991; \4-540-5/johns M.W. Sleep 1992: 15(4): 376-381 / Johns M.W. Ches11993; 103: 30-36
